author: Angie Kelly
title: Where to find the best family-friendly holidays in Australia and overseas | Travel | Travel News and Holiday Deals | |
text:
GONE are the days when colouring in and a movie in the kids’ club are enough to entertain the young ones on holiday.
Tourism marketers increasingly recognise that well-fed and imaginatively entertained junior customers means happy relaxed parents, and the likelihood the family will come back year after year.
Upping the ante on evermore innovative food and fun for families is one of the biggest trends to gain traction in hotels, ski resorts and guided holidays and no one does it better than the cruise lines.
 Royal Caribbean introduces its newest and most technologically advanced cruise ship Anthem of the Seas. Dodgems at Seaplex. Source: Supplied
CRUISES
If you can dream it, nowadays, it’s likely you can do it on a ship. Follow a zip-line across the deck with a spot of laser tag on Pacific Jewel, hit the FlowRider surfer on Voyager of the Seas or chow down on green eggs and ham before joining a life-size board game show on Carnival Spirit.
“We’re always trying to expand our horizons when it comes to ensuring kids and their parents have a great holiday,” said Carnival Cruise Lines vice-president Jennifer Vandekreeke. Cats in Hats kick off the day on Carnival Legend with the Seuss at Sea breakfast serving up a kaleidoscope of treats in a new themed event. Try pink pancake hats, red and blue waffles and those green eggs.
The Hasbro Game Show on board presents life-size versions of favourite board games Connect 4, Yahtzee, Sorry! and Operation. Carnival Spirit also has a new ocean-themed kids’ club, Camp Ocean, and will introduce Seuss at Sea later this year. P&O has just lowered the minimum age of toddlers allowed into care on all its ships from three to two years, with Pacific Jewel introducing pizzas, a burger bar, nachos and hot dogs at its new food market, The Pantry.
Coming soon: Carnival Vista will resemble a theme park at sea when it arrives in 2016, with a sky-rail ride whizzing around above the Lido Deck. The FlowRider took its first surfers out to sea this year after multimillion-dollar refits on Royal Caribbean’s Explorer of the Seas and Voyager of the Seas , which also saw the Adventure Ocean kids’ clubs upgraded.
Coming soon: Family-friendly skydiving at sea is just the start of the fun on the new superliner Ovation of the Seas , which will also have bumper cars and a carnival-style merry-go-round and an array of entertainment when it makes its maiden voyage in December 2106.
 One bedroom family beach suite in Niyama, Maldives. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
HOTELS
Children in upscale digs are now considered VIPs – perhaps nowhere more so than the Ritz Berlin where youngsters are given a toy Mercedes-Benz pedal car to get around. And a children’s turndown service with warm milk, biscuits and bathrobes is just the ticket after a day’s sightseeing at London’s Rubens Hotel, located next door to the Royal Mews.
Popular trump cards include eco activities and food. “Dining while on holiday is as much a part of the overall adventure as sightseeing,” InterContinental Resorts chef Theo Randall says.
Say goodbye to chicken nuggets and boring pasta and hello to pad thai, tomato risotto and crunchy vegies with hummus. Best-selling UK kids’ food guru Annabel Karmel is behind the new Planet Trekkers kids’ menu at all InterContinental Hotels across the globe including the Fiji and Bali resorts.
In the Maldives, well-heeled littlies staying at the new Play Island at Per Aquum’s Niyama Resort can avail themselves of in-villa spa treatments and the services of sunshine butlers who will attend to sunscreen and ice-cream requirements.
Youngsters dine in tree-house dining pods 6m above the ground – and for a change, why not try the underwater dining venue Subsix with mum and dad? Coral Kids Club at Outrigger Mauritius Beach Resort. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
Outrigger resorts on some of the world’s most iconic beaches have launched an O Zone marine education program designed to conserve ocean and reef environments off Hawaii, Fiji, Mauritius and the new Maldives resort due to open August 1. Coral planting for kids and eco activities aim to take the mobile devices out of small hands and engage children with marine life, Outrigger’s Pieter van der Hoeven says.
For the more affordable end of the scale, head for BIG4 Holiday Parks. For example, the BIG4 park in South West Rocks in NSW has spent more than $1 million this year building a new children’s attraction, Shipwreck Island waterpark and stage play area.
AIRLINES
Airlines are increasingly recognising that flying can be trying for families with young children – while the hellish discomfort of the long haul can’t be completely erased, even small changes can ease the pain.
“Our new Joey Club takes our children’s initiatives to the next level with a formal program and benefits that will make flying more fun for kids,” Qantas spokeswoman Olivia Wirth says.
As part of the new Qantas Joey Club, there will be dedicated kids’ menus in domestic lounges, more in-flight entertainment including 21 hours of kids’ movies plus a new Family Zone in the refreshed LA business lounge.
Emirates is rolling out new child-sized headsets with soft leatherette ear cushions and improved sound quality in economy class from this month on all A380 aircraft, with the Boeing 777s coming soon.
 Kids classes at Mt Hotham. Picture: Supplied Source: Supplied
SKI RESORTS
Enticing the next generation of snow lovers with on and off mountain innovations is serious business with ski resorts recognising that today’s juniors are tomorrow’s ski-dedicated grown ups.
“At Vail Resorts, investing in family-friendly facilities and activities is a top priority. We are constantly re-imagining ways that we can cater to children of all ages, both on and off the slopes,” May Lilley from Vail Resorts in the US says.
In Australia, Falls Creek in Victoria is the first resort to bring in a dedicated teen program aimed at 13 to 17-year-old skiers. The Teen Academy, for kids too old for ski school and too young for adult lessons, gets under way this season.
Expect a focus on freestyle skiing and snowboarding, barbecues in the terrain park, drone photography and video editing and screening sessions. Younger ski schoolers have a new progress booklet and sticker system while the indoor Snowclub for three to fives has new play equipment.
At Dinner Plain in Victoria, a new Snow Park has opened this season giving kids as young as five the chance to snow tube and ski.
Aspen Snowmass in Colorado, where kids ski free when you rent their gear at the resort, has opened a children’s mountain activity centre at the base of Buttermilk Mountain. There are also new discounts on group lessons.
And over at the famously family-friendly Vail-Beaver Creek resort, where on-snow chefs hand out free warm cookies to all comers at each day’s end, the Kids Adventure Zones on the learner slopes have been upgraded to include more fun ski-through features.
Meanwhile, ski with a ranger, go on a free snowshoe-headlamp adventure or hop on a new night-gondola ride up the mountain, which come complete with glow sticks.
